entity1.name: Penicillin
entity1.description: An antibiotic derived from the fungus Penicillium, used to treat bacterial infections.;;;Severe illnesses that have a high risk of causing death if left untreated or improperly managed.;;;Microscopic single-celled organisms that can exist either as independent organisms or as parasites.;;;A type of fungus that grows in the form of multicellular filaments called hyphae.;;;Infections caused by bacteria, which can affect various parts of the body and may require antibiotic treatment.;;;Ongoing efforts in the scientific community to develop new methods and drugs to combat microbial infections, especially those resistant to existing treatments.;;;An antibiotic derived from the fungus Penicillium, which was discovered by Alexander Fleming and has had a significant impact on medical treatments.;;;A class of medications that kill or inhibit the growth of bacteria and are used to treat bacterial infections.;;;A widely used antibiotic derived from the fungus Penicillium, known for its ability to treat bacterial infections.;;;Newly developed drugs or therapies aimed at effectively treating bacterial infections, particularly those caused by resistant strains.;;;Bacterial populations that have developed resistance to one or more antibiotics, making them difficult to treat with conventional therapies.;;;An antibiotic derived from the fungus Penicillium, which was successfully purified by Howard Florey and Ernst Chain's team in the early 1940s.;;;A class of substances that can inhibit or kill bacteria, used in treating bacterial infections.;;;The administration of antibiotic medications to treat bacterial infections, which should be done prudently to avoid resistance.;;;An antibiotic derived from Penicillium fungi, first discovered in 1928 by Alexander Fleming.;;;A fungus that grows in the form of multicellular filaments called hyphae, often visible to the naked eye and appearing as spots or patches.;;;The administration or prescription of antibiotic medications in medical practice, which should be done responsibly to prevent resistance.;;;An antibiotic derived from Penicillium fungi, used to treat bacterial infections.;;;A class of medications used to treat bacterial infections.;;;The ability of bacteria to resist the effects of antibiotics, leading to ineffective treatment and potential spread of resistant strains.;;;A group of bacteria that can cause various infections in humans.;;;A class of antimicrobial drugs used in the treatment and prevention of bacterial infections.;;;A type of bacteria that can cause various infections in humans and animals.;;;A life-threatening condition that arises when the body's response to an infection causes systemic inflammation and organ dysfunction.;;;The practice of diagnosing, treating, and preventing diseases caused by pathogens such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites.;;;Disease-causing bacteria that can lead to various infections in humans and animals.;;;Illnesses caused by pathogenic microorganisms, such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites that can be spread directly or indirectly from one person to another.;;;A phenomenon where bacteria evolve mechanisms to withstand the effects of antibiotics designed to kill or inhibit them.;;;A significant milestone in medical history that revolutionized the treatment of bacterial infections and saved countless lives.;;;A class of drugs used to treat bacterial infections.;;;An antibiotic derived from the fungus Penicillium, discovered by Alexander Fleming in 1928.;;;Diseases caused by harmful bacteria that can affect various parts of the body.;;;Bacteria that have developed resistance to antibiotics, making them difficult to treat with conventional medications.;;;A group of fungi, some species of which are known for producing penicillin, an antibiotic.

entity5.name: healthcare
entity5.description: The maintenance or improvement of health via the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease, illness, injury, and other physical and mental impairments in human beings.

entity6.name: Sir Alexander Fleming
entity6.description: A scientist known for his discovery of penicillin.;;;A scientist who discovered penicillin.;;;Alexander Fleming, a Scottish physician and microbiologist known for discovering penicillin.;;;A Scottish bacteriologist and Nobel laureate who discovered penicillin in 1928.;;;A Scottish bacteriologist known for the discovery of penicillin.

entity7.name: Scottish
entity7.description: Refers to people or things from Scotland, a country that is part of the United Kingdom.

entity9.name: St.
entity9.description: A common abbreviation for a street name or a saint's name, depending on the context.

entity10.name: Mary's Hospital
entity10.description: A hospital located in London, England.

entity11.name: London
entity11.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

entity27.name: Howard Florey
entity27.description: A scientist who led the team that successfully purified penicillin at the University of Oxford in the early 1940s.

entity28.name: Ernst Chain
entity28.description: A scientist who, along with Howard Florey, led the team that successfully purified penicillin at the University of Oxford in the early 1940s.

entity29.name: University of Oxford
entity29.description: A prestigious university located in Oxford, England, where Howard Florey and Ernst Chain led a team that purified penicillin.

entity32.name: World War II
entity32.description: A global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945, involving the vast majority of the world's nations and characterized by significant civilian and military casualties.

entity34.name: war
entity34.description: A period of armed conflict between different countries or different groups within a country.

entity35.name: soldiers
entity35.description: Individuals who serve in the military, often involved in combat operations.

entity36.name: civilians
entity36.description: People who are not members of the military or any other fighting force.

entity43.name: pneumonia
entity43.description: Infections caused by Streptococcus bacteria, which can affect various parts of the body including the throat, skin, and lungs.;;;A lung infection that can be caused by various bacteria, viruses, or fungi.

entity56.name: global public health
entity56.description: The overall health of the population on a global scale, encompassing efforts to improve health and prevent disease worldwide.

entity59.name: stewardship programs
entity59.description: Programs designed to optimize the treatment of infections while reducing adverse events and the emergence of antibiotic resistance.
